case_id: State of M.P. v. Babulal (2008) 1 SCC 234 / AIR 2008 SC 582
facts: Location: Village Madhupuri, P.S. Binaganj, District Guna, Madhya Pradesh.
Parties: Accused - Babulal (Respondent in SC), Lalkishan, Chhota @ Rakesh, Smt. Ramkumari Bai, Smt. Kalibai. Victim - Gabbar (Deceased). Injured Witness - Hiralal (PW-1, brother of deceased).

Sequence of Events: A dispute existed over a pathway. On the day of the incident, Gabbar and Hiralal (PW-1) were confronted by the accused party. An altercation ensued. Babulal allegedly struck Gabbar on the head with a 'farsi' (a sharp-edged weapon). Other accused allegedly attacked with lathis.
Outcome of Attack: Gabbar sustained a severe head injury and died on the spot. Hiralal (PW-1) also sustained injuries.

Evidence: FIR lodged by Hiralal (PW-1). Testimony of eyewitnesses Hiralal (PW-1, injured), Smt. Shankuntala Bai (PW-2), Smt. Bhuribai (PW-3). Medical evidence from Dr. R.K. Jain (PW-10) who conducted the post-mortem on Gabbar and examined Hiralal.

Post-Mortem Findings (Gabbar): Incised wound on the head (12 cm x 3 cm x brain deep), fracture of frontal, parietal, and temporal bones, brain matter protruding. Cause of death: Coma due to head injury caused by hard and sharp object.
Hiralal's Injuries: Lacerated wound on head, contusions.

Trial Court Judgment: Convicted Babulal under Section 302 IPC (Life Imprisonment). Acquitted all other accused. Also convicted Babulal under Section 324 IPC for injuring Hiralal (details less focused in SC appeal).

High Court Judgment: Allowed Babulal's appeal partially. Acquitted Babulal of the charge under Section 302 IPC. Convicted Babulal under Section 326 IPC for causing grievous hurt to Hiralal (PW-1) and sentenced him to 3 years Rigorous Imprisonment. Implicitly altered the finding regarding Gabbar's death to not being murder.
Supreme Court Appeal: Filed by the State of M.P. challenging the High Court's acquittal of Babulal under Section 302 IPC.
ipc_sections: Section 304 (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - Part I and Part II, discussed as alternative)
Section 326 (Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means - HC conviction for injury to Hiralal)
Section 324 (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means - Trial court conviction for injury to Hiralal)
Section 148 (Rioting, armed with deadly weapon - Initial charge)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in law and fact by acquitting Babulal under Section 302 IPC; the evidence clearly established murder under Section 300 Clause Thirdly.
precedents: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1958 SC 465)
State of Andhra Pradesh v. Rayavarapu Punnayya (1976) 4 SCC 382
Jai Prakash v. State (Delhi Administration) (1991) 2 SCC 32
elements: Death of Gabbar was caused by Babulal.
Babulal intended to cause the specific bodily injury inflicted (head injury with farsi).
The intended bodily injury was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.

counter_arguments.loophole: The act involved a single blow, suggesting lack of pre-meditation and intention to kill, potentially falling under Section 304 Part I or II.
supporting_precedents: Jagrup Singh v. State of Haryana (1981) 3 SCC 616
Mer Dhana Sida v. State of Gujarat (1985) 1 SCC 200
Pappu v. State of M.P. (2006) 7 SCC 391

counter_arguments.loophole: The incident arose out of a sudden quarrel over a pathway, possibly invoking Exception 4 to Section 300 IPC (Sudden Fight).
supporting_precedents: Sukhbir Singh v. State of Haryana (2002) 3 SCC 327
Surain Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1976 SC 2164)
Ghapoo Yadav v. State of M.P. (2003) 3 SCC 528

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court wrongly minimized the gravity by focusing only on 'single blow', ignoring the nature of weapon (farsi), vital body part targeted (head), and force used.
precedents: Anda v. State of Rajasthan (AIR 1966 SC 148)
Dhupa Chamar v. State of Bihar (2002) 6 SCC 506
Gurmail Singh v. State of Punjab (1991 Supp (1) SCC 189)
elements: Injury was inflicted on a vital part (head).
Force indicated intent to cause severe harm sufficient to cause death.

counter_arguments.loophole: Absence of repeated blows can indicate lack of determined intention to kill.
supporting_precedents: Ram Prakash Singh v. State of Bihar (AIR 1971 SC 1310)
Kunhayippu v. State of Kerala (2000) 10 SCC 307
Chamru Budhwa v. State of M.P. (AIR 1954 SC 652)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Eyewitness testimonies (PW-1, PW-2, PW-3) were consistent, reliable, and corroborated by medical evidence (PW-10); PW-1 being an injured witness adds credibility.
precedents: State of UP v. Naresh (2001) 4 SCC 324 (on injured witness credibility)
Anil Rai v. State of Bihar (2001) 7 SCC 318 (on consistency and corroboration)
Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras (AIR 1957 SC 614) (on quality vs quantity of witnesses)

counter_arguments.loophole: Witnesses might be related or interested, requiring careful scrutiny.
supporting_precedents: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1953 SC 364)
Hari Obula Reddy v. State of A.P. (1981) 3 SCC 675
M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly concluded that the offence did not amount to murder (S. 302); the conviction should remain either acquittal from S. 302 or at most S. 304 IPC.
edge_cases: Principle of limited interference by the Supreme Court in appeals against acquittal unless the High Court judgment is perverse or clearly erroneous.
Distinction between intention required for S. 300 Clause Thirdly and knowledge sufficient for S. 304 Part II.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415
Appabhai v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1988 SC 696)
State of U.P. v. Ram Veer Singh (2007) 13 SCC 102

defense_arguments.argument: The single blow inflicted during a sudden dispute over a pathway lacks the requisite intention or knowledge for murder; Exception 4 to S. 300 or classification under S. 304 is more appropriate.
edge_cases: Applicability of Exception 4 (Sudden Fight) requires showing the incident occurred without premeditation, in heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel, and without undue advantage or cruelty.
precedents: Pappu v. State of M.P. (2006) 7 SCC 391
Chamru Budhwa v. State of M.P. (AIR 1954 SC 652)
Randhir Singh @ Dhire v. State of Punjab (2004) 13 SCC 129

defense_arguments.argument: High Court's assessment of evidence was plausible and based on established legal principles regarding single-blow injuries.
edge_cases: When two views are possible on evidence, the view favouring the accused, especially in an appeal against acquittal, should generally be preferred.
precedents: Arun Kumar v. State of U.P. (AIR 1989 SC 1445)
State of Rajasthan v. Raja Ram (2003) 8 SCC 180
Mohan Singh v. State of M.P. (AIR 1999 SC 883)

judgment.outcome: Appeal allowed. The judgment of the High Court acquitting Babulal under Section 302 IPC was set aside. The judgment of the Trial Court convicting Babulal under Section 302 IPC and sentencing him to life imprisonment was restored. The conviction and sentence under Section 326 IPC (imposed by High Court for injury to Hiralal) were maintained and directed to run concurrently.
reasoning: The High Court's approach in acquitting the accused under S. 302 was found to be erroneous and based on irrelevant considerations.

The court emphasized that intention (mens rea) is crucial. While determining intention, factors like the nature of the weapon, the part of the body attacked, the force used, and the circumstances are vital.
The weapon used ('farsi') was a sharp, dangerous weapon.
The blow was inflicted on a vital part of the body - the head.
The force was significant, causing extensive skull fracture and brain damage.
These factors collectively established the intention to cause bodily injury sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, bringing the act squarely within Section 300 Clause Thirdly.
The High Court gave undue importance to the fact that it was a 'single blow' without properly appreciating the other factors.
Exception 4 (Sudden Fight) was held inapplicable as the evidence suggested the accused party came armed and initiated the assault; there was no evidence of sudden provocation or fight on equal terms.
The eyewitness testimonies (PW-1, PW-2, PW-3) were found reliable and consistent, corroborated by medical evidence (PW-10). PW-1's testimony as an injured eyewitness carried significant weight.

The Supreme Court reiterated the principles for appeal against acquittal but found the High Court's judgment unsustainable based on the evidence and established legal principles regarding Section 300 Clause Thirdly.
